vocabulary.example: a traveler [n] - a beer that you can carry to the next bar

vocabulary.word: one thing I'll give old XXX is
vocabulary.translation: одно, что я ценю в XXX, это
vocabulary.example: one thing I'll give old Paris is [exp] - something that I admire about Paris is
open container laws [exp] - laws that allow people to drink alcohol on the street
get on the lash [exp] - getting drunk
taking the piss [exp] - making fun of, teasing
the board [n] - the white board at the front of the classroom
abstract [adj] - theoretical, not concrete, not practical
immerse [v] - use or engage fully or deeply
come over me [phv] - affect me, happen to me
Not bothered [exp] - I am not angry. It does not bother me
She is so into me [exp] - She really likes or fancies me

questions.question: Emily and Alfie are drinking what?
One thing that Alfie likes about Paris is that what?
options: you can drink on the street
the weather is better than in London

questions.question: Who wants to skip French class?
Alfie invites Emily to what tonight?
Emily and Alfie got what scores on their tests?
The teacher is trying to what with Alfie?
What does Emily do when Alfie makes a mistake at the board?
The teacher suggests that Emily is improving because of what reasons?
options: she is a little drunk and not thinking too much
she has been studying more and spending time with French people
she is a little drunk and spending time with French people
she has been studying more and not thinking too much

questions.question: Alfie is what at the teacher?

transcript.full:
Alfie: There you go.

Emily: Ooh, coffee! Good idea.

Alfie: It's a traveler, Cooper.

Emily: Mmm-hmm! Oh, that's, that's beer! What did you call it?

Alfie: A traveler. To drink whilst you're traveling to the next bar.

Emily: Or French class.

Alfie: You know, one thing I'll give old Paris, open container laws, I mean you can get on the lash wherever you want.

Emily: I don't think that's true.

Alfie: Well, I haven't been nicked yet. Maybe tonight's the night. You fancy getting banged up abroad, Cooper?

Emily: You know, the more you drink, the more British you sound. Are you sure we're not too drunk for French class? Should we skip it?

Alfie: Can't. Need to get my little attendance slip signed for work. Don't worry, love. We'll be hunky-dory.

Emily: Hunky-dory? Oh, now you're just taking the piss. I'm a fast learner.

Teacher: I hope you both find your grades as funny.

Teacher: Alfie, can you join me at the board, please. So, one common mistake in the test was people using 'je suppose' instead of 'j'imagine.' They're very similar, but 'j'imagine' is more abstract.

Teacher: Alfie, can you write on the board, please, 'J'imagine que je suis en vacances.'

Alfie: What was the rest?

Teacher: Non, pas Jean Magine. J'imagine.

Alfie: Yeah, that's what I wrote.

Teacher: No.

Alfie: Who the hell's Jean Magine, anyway?

Teacher: En francais, s'il vous plait.

Alfie: Qui est Jean Magine?

Emily: I imagine Alfie's doing his best. He doesn't have much opportunity to speak with many French people.

Alfie: Now that was bloody brilliant! What did she say?

Teacher: Emily! Well done. Tonight for the first time, you fully immersed yourself in the language. You didn't overthink it.

Emily: Merci. I don't know really what came over me, but maybe it's the heatwave.

Teacher: Yeah, or whatever's in that cup. Alfie, I wish I could say the same to you.

Alfie: All good. Not bothered.

Teacher: I didn't think so. Hmm. Bonne nuit.

Alfie: She is so into me.
